body: I'll have a look and see if I can fix it.

*  in the search results there should be a space between the number and "spans"

resolved  by #2434

LGTM
thanks! please add the "how it works" image to the README at the bottom under a markdown section named design or a separate DESIGN.md
@drolando I missed this list. thank you so much!
Looks good besides the blowup. I tested uploading a v2 json and also get trace by ID

ps I checked Gerald already has an ASF iCLA http://people.apache.org/unlistedclas.html

While we haven't yet moved this repo, it will soon.

What language are you instrumenting?

Den tir. 19. mar. 2019, 07:17 skrev Aaron Stainback <
notifications@github.com>:

> If I have already sent a {cs,cr} or {sr,cs} with a duration is it possible
> to "overwrite" what's currently there? This seems to work fine if the first
> duration I sent was 0 then I can still update it in the future but if the
> first duration I sent was anything else I can't seem to overwrite it with a
> new duration. Any help is appreciated. Thanks.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/2452>, or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AC7sAsefWgGXXhyCIhDx6bx1rDcV0mZaks5vYIEBgaJpZM4b7XRc>
> .
>

It is better to send in v2 format, and duration explicitly vs derived. duration can be written again, but be careful to use correct instrumentation. For example, a shared field needs to be set if there is a server span re-using the same ID as the client. Otherwise duration precedence on merge will get messed up.

I'm sending v2 protobuf format directly https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-api/blob/master/zipkin.proto.  Let's completely ignore the server span for right now and only talk about the client span.  I'm sending the exact same client span twice, except the first time I'm sending `uint64 duration` of 1 and the 2nd time I'm sending `uint64 duration` of 1234.  The UI never sees 1234, it only sees 1.

If I change the setup and on the first time I send `uint64 duration` 0 then the 2nd time I send `uint64 duration` of 1234 then in the UI I see 1234.

Are you saying the 2nd time I should set the shared flag?  I'll try that and let you know the results.
it is best to not report duration unless you know what it is. why is it that you are sending a tentative duration?
so not send duration meaning leave absent (zero is often coersed to absent as we define minimal duration of 1 due to nuance on this point)

**If uploaded file is not JSON...**

![not-json](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19551419/54586341-13bd4e00-4a60-11e9-91ab-5abf4c01d892.gif)

**If v1 format file is uploaded...**

![v1-trace](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19551419/54586353-1ddf4c80-4a60-11e9-94ff-36fa64cb8279.gif)

Because the process I'm instrumenting does not really know if it's complete.  It can keep getting woken up over and over and it never really knows if it's done, I would just like to report the best currently known information.

so the problem is that certain tools will not expect varying duration as the general span contract is you start it, you finish it (once). Things like duration query won't work right when the value changes. Most stores are document oriented as opposed to SQL upsert. Readback might be ok. At any rate, problems like this are why we added the "shared" flag to the server span, so that it could be ignored when computing the client duration.

my guess is that what you are experiencing is tension on span model as what you are modeling doesn't seem to have a defined start and finish. It might be helpful to be more concrete about what's going on as perhaps there are ways to model it differently.. not sure. there are some things that don't work well with span model, like chat sessions.
goodie!

Got ya, so you are saying it's not designed to work this way.  Can I always assume I can "update" an existing span that has no duration?  Like my 2nd scenario above, initially sending "empty" and then later sending a value for the same span id.  This is nice because at least I can see in the UI the "empty" span before the final span with duration will be received. Again I'm not just talking about client/server scenario.  I'm talking about all span types.

yes you can send any fields late except trace id/span id. We did this for the use case of in-flight data that isn't complete actually :) before we had to play games with fields initialized to empty string.
I should clarify it is more efficient to send as much of it at the same time (ideally complete). anyway hope this answers the question.
With any backend will they show up in the UI "early" before they have a duration as they do with the in-memory backend?

@AceHack no backend requires duration, though display won't look great lacking one.

timestamp is important though.. please send that if you can. It is also in some aggregation cases helpful. meaning if you have to send duration late, it can help some tooling to send timestamp in the same doc.
PS I will add a unit test referencing this issue to ensure late duration is ok
Do you have a list of common or standard tags and annotations?

@AceHack usually I would have punted to gitter by now but I thought we were at the end of the duration dillemma :) can we chase up other questions on gitter as this is starting to spam the repo https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin
Okay thanks.
cc @openzipkin/armeria in case y'all have insight into this. This started after the switcheroo and maybe there's an easy explanation/setting somewhere

Confirming with `java -jar zipkin.jar --logging.level.root=TRACE` that the `armeriaServer` bean indeed is taking a long time to destroy:

>2019-03-19 09:14:25.531 TRACE 28697 --- [       Thread-5] o.s.b.f.s.DisposableBeanAdapter          : Invoking destroy method 'close' on bean with name 'cassandraCluster'
2019-03-19 **09:14:25.555** TRACE 28697 --- [       Thread-5] o.s.b.f.s.DisposableBeanAdapter          : Invoking destroy method 'close' on bean with name 'armeriaServer'
2019-03-19 **09:14:32.784** TRACE 28697 --- [       Thread-5] o.s.b.f.s.DisposableBeanAdapter          : Invoking destroy() on bean with name 'defaultValidator'
2019-03-19 09:14:32.784 TRACE 28697 --- [       Thread-5] o.s.b.f.s.DefaultListableBeanFactory     : Retrieved dependent beans for bean 'prometheusMeterRegistry': [metrics, zipkin2.server.internal.MetricsHealthController, metricsEndpoint, zipkin2.autoconfigure.prometheus.ZipkinPrometheusMetricsAutoConfiguration, metricsRestTemplateCustomizer]
2019-03-19 09:14:32.784 TRACE 28697 --- [       Thread-5] o.s.b.f.s.DefaultListableBeanFactory     : Retrieved dependent beans for bean 'metrics': [zipkin2.server.internal.ZipkinHttpCollector]

Some things I'd like to see:
* A way to reset zoom
* Zooming into a certain time frame will filter the spans below to only those that were open during the window. (and all of it's parent spans back to the root for contextual info). This would help manage "tall" traces

We do not offer support for custom-built servers anymore (using `@EnableZipkinServer`), but it is still possible for you to make them, technically. Join us on Gitter (https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin) and share what is your use case for wanting to make a custom build. Perhaps there are ways to achieve your goals without making a custom server.

This looks like it could be a solution to our current kubernetes problem. We have many environments tracing and all of the traces are stored in one backend. We want to add meta tags such as the environment for all tracing.

It would be nice if https://github.com/afalko/zipkin-generic-enrichment-filter/blob/master/src/main/java/net/afalko/zipkin/filter/GenericEnrichmentFilter.java was bundled as a part of zipkin. It seems to work in the spirit of 12FA.

Any reasons this hasn't progressed?

hi there are a couple reasons this hasn't progressed. firstly the initial PR has been obviated by a Kafka alternative at Salesforce I think.

the other thing is that there is a glitch not everyone is aware of. at the collector layer we aren't guaranteed to see the whole trace. this means only stateless ops limited to scrubbing or adding tags based only on the current span is possible. to consider the whole trace we need a buffer like Kafka or a tiered storage like voltdb.

if your requirements are limited to things like data filtering or addition (and not pruning layers of the trace or other trace scoped things) indeed this would sort it (as would an elasticsearch pipeline stage)

can you verify that all you need to do are stateless ops that apply to all spans?

Thanks for getting back to me @adriancole.

I don't think we would require the whole trace as we can search the trace via a tag in any span. So in theory this should be good enough.

We're using stackdriver as a backend so can't leverage any ES pipeline stages.

To give some context we want to add an environment tag for context. This will allow us to know which environment the trace has come from i.e. prod, pre-prod, integration
@adriancole Sounds good. We can test these changes for sure as it's going to be something we need and feels like the most elegant way of implementing it from our perspective.

@benjefferies @adriancole this what we would using at Salesforce when I was there 7 months ago: https://github.com/afalko/zipkin-storage-kafka and https://github.com/afalko/zipkin-storage-filters...it is essentially a set of jars that you add to your Zipkin deploy to intercept spans and do what you will with them. You can change anything about the Spans except http-level things like headers. For those, we had a proxy sitting in front of Zipkin. 

+1 to the FinishedSpanHandler idea. That would simplified things for us.

My guess is this will introduce problems like the following if you are able to get the tests to pass (usually ES doesn't work with a wide version range, at least right now we are rev-locked using their library in zipkin-dependencies). We need to make sure the cure isn't worse than the disease.

Here are some things you'd hit if you continue:

This will break the auth integration in the zipkin-aws repository. For example, an interceptor doing AWS authentication exists there.

This will break the env variables used to debug connections with the logging interceptor.

This will break compile on the builder, which we try not to do, as eventhough we don't support custom servers the storage library might be used directly (even if probably few would).

Finally, this might have some library skew management besides elasticsearch themselves. Should look at the dependencies especially what their v7 library will have.

I do have hesitations about the elasticsearch (apache httpclient based) library, mentioned above. Full disclosure I personally prefer okhttp and enjoy coding with it... this module has been easy to support for years and often times authors of change switch direction. Wanting to maintain something is important.

Having something others are happy to maintain is an important part of the decision. For example, @anuraaga wrote the original one, but he uses stackdriver now. IIRC @jcarres-mdsol uses this in AWS, eventhough the first AWS user was @devinsba. People change roles and integrations like this fade out of focus. It may fade out of focus for you in a year who knows.. that's why we need buy in.

Let's say tests pass without dropping versions, aws still works etc.. To answer your question directly about mergability.  I'd like to see another maintainer who isn't currently required to use elasticsearch ok with helping maintain this. We should also revise our support policy in that case to follow elasticsearch's which will affect end sites. For example, if they haven't already dropped a version we support, you can guarantee they will. We need to be transparent with users that our support range will be in elasticsearch's hands if this is merged. If other committers are on-board even if you or I step away, I'm fine on it.

I would prefer that similar effort was made to address whatever the problem is in okhttp though as that would break less people. However, yeah I mean what I said, if other folks can get behind this, I'd also be ok.
this is a good question. can you please ask on gitter or stackoverflow? we use issues for changes to the project code. https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin
Great work, @tacigar!

I understand. I won't argue, thanks for this detailed answer.

circleci does parallel tests I think it isn't getting the change to core propagated to collector. since ASF we can't use circleci anyway I'm merging and hoping for the best :P
Is graceful shutdown enabled? ~(It's disabled if not configured.)~

It looks like graceful shutdown might be enabled by default

https://github.com/line/armeria/blob/master/spring/boot-autoconfigure/src/main/java/com/linecorp/armeria/spring/ArmeriaSettings.java#L190

I think this is because graceful shutdowns is a good default for normal servers, though since tracing is often best effort maybe should be changed in zipkin server

The quiet period is how long the server will wait for requests to go away. The timeout is the maximum amount of time it will wait - with a load balancer configured for the health point, the quiet period will generally be enough for shutdown but without that the server will always wait until the timeout of 40s.

To disable graceful shutdown on zipkin server, we should probably disable both settings - though @adriancole should make the call as enabling graceful by default can also reduce gotchas in default configurations.
thanks, I will test post-merge

So before we switched to armeria, we didn't have such a long quiet period.
So in this case, I think we should disable the settings by default as folks
wouldn't have relied on them formerly and the first time experience isn't
great with them on either.

@IAMTJW @moekelley76 can you put your vote on the original issue with thumbsup? https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/1990

On Tue, Mar 26, 2019 at 12:55 AM Gerald Quintana
<notifications@github.com> wrote:
>
> there is an existing issue about this. hard coding basic auth credentials is probably not something we would want to standardize on for obvious reasons.
>
> Reasons are not so obvious to me. Can you explain?

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Use_of_hard-coded_password and a bunch
of other posts. The background issue (the one I linked, not what you
created) also mentions that people have different ideas when it comes
to auth. For example api keys, mutual TLS, oauth, etc. That and many
are not using http for span data either (ex disable it), and the
options for messaging security are a bit random. I don't want to
wander this issue, all I meant to say is that there are some problems
including the vulnerability aspects and depending on impl whether the
server reboots to see a new password and how exactly such a password
change would roll out to your instrumented apps. I remember this a
decade ago was a bit of an issue. Making a default for basic auth
would imply for us at least thinking that through which I think some
would reasonably say "please don't do basic auth". This is why I'm
more interested in seeing how to allow you to opt in. I would prefer
debates about whether basic is smart or not to remain on the other
issue. This one, I'm trying to help see if you can enable it on your
own.

@openzipkin/armeria

Hi, I believe you were asking this on gitter, which is the correct place to do this. The same people who would work on an issue have been trying to help you there. Please try to explain on gitter. I feel perhaps there are some translation issues, but we'll get through them.

Let's assume we are talking about activemq (not artemis or apollo)

I like that activemq has very few dependencies, however they do add 2MiB weight to the server.
```

$ jar -tvf activemq.jar
```

@gquintana would the features available here get you by? if so I could try to get an example together https://github.com/line/armeria/blob/master/core/src/main/java/com/linecorp/armeria/server/auth/HttpAuthServiceBuilder.java

Thanks for the feedback @adriancole.  I've taken the in-process approach before.  One of the downsides is it's really difficult to aggregate across multiple instances of the same service.  I've ended up implementing a banding based approach as suggested on https://www.vividcortex.com/blog/why-percentiles-dont-work-the-way-you-think .  Downside is that the implementation ends up being specific to the web framework used (e.g. Spring Boot or Dropwizard) and so needs implementing multiple times if you use more than 1 framework in your estate.  

Haystack seems interesting, though it's quite a big addition just to compute percentiles.  

Are there any thoughts/plans to implement summary/aggregte level views in Zipkin in the future or will it always stay at the level of finding and then viewing individual traces?  Thanks!

How important is performance here, and what's the performance like for this implementation? ActiveMQ 5.x isn't particularly high-performance at this point given its underlying architecture, and storing messages in a database further slows things down. I'm new to Zipkin so I'm curious. Thanks!

usually performance of the collector is secondary to applicability. for
example, the most applicable transport to a site is a differentiator as it
allows them to use it. a high performance but not applicable answer is just
code to maintain. that is why we do things like "rule of 3" and other
guards to ensure the transports are viable to the most folks.

currently we have no other existing issue about aggregation on percentiles
besides this. to be honest with you is to say that this issue would need a
lot more buy in as it impacts all storage options.

right now we do have duration query but you would need to use a different
tool to decide which duration matters. that is the most honest assessment
of status quo.

if there is something about haystack that could be made easier I would ask
to give them that feedback. they are nice and earnest people. if matters
less if you are able to use their stuff..  rather a nice gesture to tell
them what's up.

> Thanks for the feedback @adriancole <https://github.com/adriancole>. I've
> taken the in-process approach before. One of the downsides is it's really
> difficult to aggregate across multiple instances of the same service. I've
> ended up implementing a banding based approach as suggested on
> https://www.vividcortex.com/blog/why-percentiles-dont-work-the-way-you-think
> . Downside is that the implementation ends up being specific to the web

Is a few hundred messages per second considered near the top-end of the potential volume?

@jbertram depending on bundling mechanics, higher throughput can be thousands or tens of thousands per second. Higher throughput sites often run multiple collectors though. I would say that most users will not be doing more than a thousand of messages/second.

In the future, this may change as more people explore the costs involved in unsampled (usually this means late sampled, or tiered) collection. For example, we have a https://github.com/adriancole/zipkin-voltdb experiment which can swallow a lot more data than most storage backends. If someone doing 1k messages per second at 1% decides to do 100%, that means multiplying the throughput. For example, some doing what we call "firehose mode" like yelp, they had to write custom collectors as they went over what their kafka setup could do. This is more a thought for you vs what's commonly the case now. I mean to hint there could be some sites doing 100k messages/second into a short term buffer, even if I have no idea when that would be practiced and what the sharding of that rate would typically look like.

Back to reality :)

You'll notice some mentioning the order of thousands of spans per second here. No one currently is using activemq, but that's what this issue is about :) spans should be bundled (ex many spans per message), so if you have say.. 8k spans/second, ideally this is bundled into <1k messages/second of size in orders of low kilobytes.

https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/ZIPKIN/Sites

I'll ask some of the sites to provide more fine grained details on bundling mechanics. Thanks very much for the interest!

some findings I think.. so I looked at some change to let spring-security work with reactive (by @rwinch). It seems that spring-security is largely servlet based. Currently our web controllers are armeria which directly implement over netty I think... this is both read and write endpoints.

* Getting auth is one thing (basically wiring in an `ArmeriaServerConfigurator` which decorates it).
* Getting spring-security is another (probably doing some sort of adapter model)

To solve things at the correct layer of abstraction, if spring-security implementation is important to you, I think it should be an issue request here https://github.com/line/armeria

Regardless, in general we suggest using a proxy or gateway and/or turning off endpoints not needed. We made [this example](https://github.com/openzipkin/docker-zipkin/tree/master/zipkin-ui#zipkin-ui) for exactly the reason of security templating. Another example, Tyro are a bank and they simply disable query where it should not be used and visa versa for the collector endpoint. I'm repeating stuff already discussed in #782 for context only. We can track this issue independently for what is viable for basic auth as a "at your own risk" add-on to the server.

Note: I found a couple classes that might be relevant for armeria+spring security.

As far as I understand, this is wrapping the servlet-based code so that it can be re-used in spring webflux

https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/b93528138e2b2f7ad34d10a040e6b7ac50fc587a/web/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/web/server/WebFilterChainProxy.java
https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/b93528138e2b2f7ad34d10a040e6b7ac50fc587a/config/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/config/annotation/web/reactive/WebFluxSecurityConfiguration.java#L60

> One of the downsides is it's really difficult to aggregate across multiple instances of the same service. 

This is true if you compute percentiles in the application before shipping them. Clearly percentile data itself is non-aggregable across dimensions. 

This is what percentile approximations off of discretized histogram data is designed to solve. See things like [histogram_quantile](https://prometheus.io/docs/prometheus/latest/querying/functions/#histogram_quantile). The individual histograms for several dimensions (say a host dimension) can be aggregated by pairwise summing the buckets and then performing the calculation off of the summed histogram.

Even percentiles may not be as useful as you folks think, depending on the application. If what you are really after as a business is saying "I want no more than 1% of my users to experience a greater than 10ms latency", once way of viewing this is that the 99th percentile needs to be less than 10ms. Another way of looking at this is to simply count how many requests are less than 10ms, and then  `(total_throughput - count_less_than_10ms) / total_throughput <= 0.01`. This latter approach is far cheaper than even computing percentile approximations over discretized histogram data.

Bottom line: percentile data needs to be computed off of either 100% sampled tracing data (haystack) or metrics telemetry (aggregated). Trying to reason about a distribution from downsampled data is a fool's errand.
